Graphical abstract A comprehensive comparision of the voltage, capacity, rate, cycle life of organic cathode materials for zinc batteries and corresponding summary strategies toward high performance zinc organic batteries. Energy sustainable development has stimulated the pursuit of an eco-friendly energy storage system. Carbon peak and neutrality targets oriented energy storage development will guide the way of further studies on batteries system. However, conventional batteries system (lead-acid batteries, lithium-ion batteries) based on ungreen transition metal oxide, flammable electrolytes or hazardous metals cannot keep pace with the development of society sooner or later. Thus, vast explorations on the advanced rechargeable battery systems were conducted. Compared with other battery systems, zinc ion battery systems with inherent safety, low cost were widely investigated. Especially, the zinc organic batteries based on the eco-efficiency organic cathodes were promising alternative advanced batteries for future energy storage systems. Therefore, various organics and different electrochemistry mechanisms were explored in the zinc batteries system. Herein, a timely review on elaborate analysis about functional groups, fundamentals, progress accompanied by the discussion on the four core issues: voltage, capacity, rate performance, cycle life was presented. Specifically, aiming at these issues, three levels of solution strategies: materials design concepts, morphology structure optimization and electrolyte environment were summarized and proposed for the development and innovation of zinc organic batteries. Keywords Organic materials Zinc batteries Optimization strategies 1 Introduction Green energy and environmental sustainability are regarded as two major topics in the 21st century. Also, stressing the emission peak and carbon neutrality targets have been added to China’s overall plan for ecological conservation. The efficient conversion and storage of energy have become a hot topic at present. However, exploration of the development of eco-friendly energy sources such as wind and solar energy is vastly restricted by their irregular production and inability to continuous energy supply [1,2]. Thus, energy storage is essential to enhance the reliability of electric power systems. Li-ion batteries (LIBs) have dominant the energy storage systems since their introduction by Sony [3-5]. LIBs are widely used in electronics including laptops, digital cameras, mobile phones, electric vehicles even grid-level energy storage systems[6]. Nevertheless, the potential safety hazards of LIBs are still an obsession, as well as the poor resource reserve, and high cost of lithium, which limited the application of LIBs in large-scale energy storage systems [7,8]. In recent years, others battery systems including monovalent ion batteries (Na+, K+), multivalent batteries (Mg2+, Zn2+, Ca2+, Al3+) have been researched extensively [9-12]. Among them, zinc-ion batteries with the high theoretical capacity of zinc anode (820 mAh g−1), the divalent charge of Zn2+ in aqueous (mild neutral or slightly acidic)/non-aqueous (organic/ ionic liquid (IL)) electrolytes have many distinct merits over alkali metal cells (Li, Na, K, etc.) upon the safety, abundant reserves, low cost and high power capacity [13-15]. Thus zinc-ion batteries are of great potential in next-generation green batteries for large-scale stationary storage applications. Currently, inorganic cathode materials for zinc batteries mainly include manganese, vanadium [16], molybdenum-based oxides/sulfides [17] and prussian blue analogs-based materials [18]. The electrochemical mechanism of these materials relies on the redox reactions with valence state changes of metal oxidation and concomitant cations counterions and structure change balance [19]. Thus the electrochemistry process of these inorganic materials usually accompanied by lattice evolution or deposition/dissolution action, which either need to overcome the lattice energy, structural strain or face irreversible dissolution [20]. Moreover, these conventional inorganic cathodes still contain toxic or polluting elements that run counter to the development of green and sustainability [21]. Organic materials, with sustainable production, ubiquitous in nature and high reversible electrochemistry are attractive alternative energy storage materials for further energy storage systems. The electrochemistry energy storage mechanism of organic materials related to the conversion or rearrangement of covalent bonds, which is insensitive to the radius of the cation when compared to the lattice changes in inorganics [22,23]. Therefore, the charge compensation mechanism with various cations (Li+, Na+, K+, Mg2+, etc.) provided the possibility of applying these organics to zinc batteries [24]. Inspirationally, most of the organic materials, including conductivity polymers, carboxide, amine for alkali metal batteries, can also be applied in zinc batteries. Fig. 1 illustrated a brief summary of the important developing course of organics for zinc-ion batteries. Owning the contrivable, flexible and controllable tuning physical/chemistry properties (e.g., solubility, conductivity, voltage and capacity), these organics are suitable for the divalent zinc ion or anions (Cl−, SO4 2−, ClO4 − and CF3SO3 −) insertion/deinsertion reaction. Thus, exploring suitable organic materials to construct high-performance rechargeable zinc-ion batteries has become a hot topic. Although vast of studies on zinc-organic battery have reported, researches are still in its early stages, and the variability of insertion ions (anion, Zn2+, H+, or hydrated Zn2+, etc.) made the insertion mechanism complicated. Despite a few reviews about zinc organic batteries were already reported based on the classification and issues of the materials [14,25], the latest advances and a summary about the point-to-point resolution strategies still lacked. Further, given the variable characteristics of organics, it is devoid of a comprehensive and systematic review to briefly introduce the classification, fundamentals, progress, modified strategies and prospect of zinc-organic batteries. In this review, we discussed recent studies in zinc organic batteries in the classification of active groups and made a comparison upon their voltage, capacity, rate and cycle performance. Then according to these issues, strategies to improve their performance were summarized in Fig. 2 . Ultimately, we put forward the design vision and prospect of organic materials for the practical application of zinc batteries. 2 Overview Organic materials for zinc batteries were first reported based on the polyaniline (PANI) cathode and zinc as the counter electrode [26]. After that, numerous materials have been designed and applied to rechargeable zinc batteries, which including conjugated carbonyls, conjugated thioether, conjugated hydrocarbons, nitroxide radical and imine compounds, etc. However, the electrochemistry mechanism of these materials is different, and a clear overview is need to help the development of zinc organic battery system. Thus a clear classification is necessary to understand this field. In this section, we will make a classification based on the redox mechanism, then summarize the modified strategies based on the types of the materials. 2.1 Electrochemical mechanisms The electrochemical reaction sites of organic materials were based on the redox reaction functional group types. According to their different redox reactions, organics materials for zinc batteries can be categorized into three types: p-type, n-type and bipolar-type. The electrochemistry mechanism and typical compounds were displayed in Table 1 , Generally, p-type organics for zinc batteries were mainly conductive polymer, which contained aniline, pyrrole, benzpyrrole and thiophene. Bipolar type organic were mainly contained radical polymers with nitroxides moieties and polyparaphenylene (PPP). While n-type organics contented carbonyl, imine and cyano groups. During the oxidation reaction of p-type state or reduction process of the neutral n-type, anion A− (Cl−, -SO3 −, SO4 2−, BF4 − and CF3SO3 −) or cation B+ (Zn2+, H+) were neutralized the p+ or n− charge to form the p+·A− or n−·B+, respectively. While in the corresponding reverse process, anion or cation will migrate back to the electrolyte. Bipolar organics contained p or n-type moiety can be regarded as n-type or p-type for only half of the reaction occurs usually [27]. For organics, the type of redox reaction is closely associated with the electroactive organic group or moiety. Thus, we summarized the progress of zinc organic batteries based on the active groups or moieties. The general classification was the following: conductive polymer (conjugated amines, thioether, hydrocarbons), nitroxide radical polymers, conjugated carbonyl, imine compounds, nitrile compounds. From the studies conducted on aqueous/organic electrolyte-based zinc-organic or corresponding zinc-flow batteries, we found that the research focus or modified strategies were mainly to solve the four core issues: voltage, capacity, rate performance, cycle life. And some intrinsic laws about them existed: (1) Voltage, p-type organics (conductive polymers and nitroxide radical polymers with a reduction voltage plateau >0.8 V) possess a higher voltage than n-type organics (average discharge voltage of carbonyl, imine <0.8 V). And organic quinone with carbonyls in para-position generally shows a higher capacity and lower plateau gap than the one with carbonyl in ortho-position. Besides the adjacent functional group or moiety with electron-withdrawing groups (e.g., -Cl, -F, -Br, -S and –CN) or the electron-donating group (e.g., –OH, –NH2, –CH3) can elevate or lower the voltage, respectively. (2) Capacity, p/bipolar-type organics were determined by the doping level, while n-type compounds were associated with the equation: C theo = n F/M w. Here, Ctheo is the theoretical capacity, F is Faraday constant, n is transferred electrons value and M w is the molecular mass. Thus increasing n or simplifying molecular structural (M w) can improve the capacity. (3) Rate performance of materials, which was closely correlated with the electron or ionic conductivity that was defined by the doping level, conjugated structure or electrolyte systems, respectively. Besides, morphology also plays a great role in the performance. (4) Cycle life was related to the insolubility, stability of the inherent properties of materials, also the electrolyte systems can not be ignored. According to the above four issues, we summarized and divided the solution strategies for these issues into three levels: one is the molecular design including copolymerization, regulating adjacent groups (electron-withdrawing or hydrophobicity moieties), designing the rigid structure and introduction of heteroatom/metal nodes. The second is macroscopic morphological structure (e.g. carbon or inorganic hybridization, morphological control). Another is tunning the electrochemical reaction environment such as state of electrolyte (liquid, quasi-solid and all-solid) and the components (salts, solvents and additives), environment temperature and the embedded behavior. Thus, in the following section, we would introduce the study process of zinc organic batteries based on the classification of groups and analyze relevant strategies and results. 2.2 Conductive polymer Conductive polymer with π-conjugated structure and doped ions can achieve well electronic conductivity even directly comparable to that of metals. The doped ions can reversible insertion/deinsertion during the electrochemistry process, which triggered the enthusiasm on electroactive conductive polymer for rechargeable batteries since 1981 [28]. Besides, conductive polymers that undergo p/n-doping reactions can apply in cathode or anode at different voltage regions. Usually, p-type conductive polymers with an output voltage rival to inorganic electrodes in zinc battery systems were widely investigated. The following section provides a series of studies on p-type conductive polymers or corresponding inorganic hybrid materials for zinc batteries mainly including conjugated amines (Polyaniline (PANI), Polypyrrole (PPy), Polyindole (PIn)), hydrocarbons (PPP) and thioethers (PTh, PEDOT). 2.2.1 Conjugated amines Here, conjugated amines mainly including the conjugated polymers with amine groups, typically including PANI, PPy, PIn and corresponding copolymers and derivates. Further, to comprehensively present the research progress of conductive polymers, the PANI and PPy hybridized inorganic materials are also summarized in this section. As p-type conductivity polymers, they typically with high voltage and good electronic conductivity, however, relatively low capacity and electrolyte system sensibility are their main issues. And in light of these problems, methods to solve these issues including molecular design, modifying morphology, inorganics/carbon hybridization, electrolyte optimization, also the mechanism would discuss and analyze in the following section. PANI, as a branch of conductive polymer, was firstly applied in zinc batteries in 1985 [26], which presented a high voltage and decent conductivity. However, its weak acid/neutral electrolyte tolerance, capacity and rate performance need to be further improved. Thus the studies about the electrolyte, morphology, copolymerization and hybridization were conducted. (1) Optimization of the electrolyte systems These methods were precisely divided into the selection of solute, additive and solvent (aqueous, organic, ionic liquid (IL)), the state (quasi/all-solid-state) of electrolytes and the operation environment. About the solute, the studies of Zn/PANI in Cl− and SO4 2− electrolyte found that PANI loses its electrochemical activity while in weak acid or neutral solutions (pH >4) [29], and Cl− doped PANI illustrated better performance for its smaller ionic radius. Besides, electrolyte optimization methods including additive salt or solvent [30-33], ionic liquid (IL) [34], organic additive [35], organic [36], or all/quasi-solid state electrolyte [37,38] can effectively suppress this side reaction of the electrodes and prolong the cycling life. In addition, the low-temperature strategy would do a favor to the cycle stability of PANI. Zhang et al. developed a low-temperature aqueous ZnCl2 – based electrolyte by balancing the strength of H-bonds and ion interactions in solution. Due to the more Zn2+ solvation structure and less free solvent caused by the electrolyte of high concentration, PANI in the electrolyte showed an ultrawide operation temperature range of −90 ~ +60 °C, and stable cycling performance (retention ~100% after 2000 cycles at 0.2 A g−1, −70 °C) [39]. Although the electrolyte optimization can prolong the cycle life of PANI, they were still restricted by the acid electrolyte. Moreover, these optimizing strategies lack universality, and it needs to further improve. (2) Carbon hybridized PANI This stratergy either with simply mixture or in-situ electropolymerization endowing the composites with high conductive carbon matrix was the most cost-effective method to improve their performance. For example, Ghanbari et al. first incorporated different sizes and content of graphite particles into the polyaniline matrix to form PANI/G composites. The interaction between the large π-conjugated structure of graphite and quinoid rings can significantly increase the conductivity, thus it showed better performance than the pure PANI [40]. Besides, mixing PANI with CNT with porous structure can realize high wettability and ionic conductivity, and ensure high cycling stability and coulombic efficiency [41]. Carbon template method can endow PANI specific morphology and unique functionality. Here, a unique micro-nano structured polyaniline-single-walled carbon nanotube-sponge cathode (Fig. 3 a) was prepared and exhibited stable electrochemical performance (capacity retentions 90.7% after 1000 cycles at 1A g−1) and good mechanical durability even under different strains (Fig. 3b) [42]. Moreover, through controllable in-situ electropolymerization coating PANI on the carbon substrates such as carbon fiber [43], carbon felts [38], or 3D graphene [44] endowed the composites large active interface, flexible, high conductivity. For example, Kim et al. obtained a highly porous polyaniline (PANI)-coated carbon fiber (PANI/CF) (Fig. 3c) cathode possessing high surface area and conductivity (Fig. 3d), thus the battery exhibited long cycling stability (retention 87% after 100 cycles) and superior rate performance (160 mAh g−1 and 30 mAh g−1 at 1C and 600C, respectively) in an aqueous electrolyte solution (Fig. 3e) [43]. While the drawback is the relatively high loading of fluffy carbon materials will lower the energy density of the cathode. Introducing a high mass density carbon base will relieve the issues. Recently, the polyaniline nanorod arrays PANI-10, PANI-400 were prepared by tunable chemical oxidation polymerization PANI on carbon fiber. The unique nanorod arrays presented good wettability with electrolyte, which enables the full use of their pseudocapacitance and promotes the diffusion of electrolyte ions, thereby improving the rate performance of zinc-ion batteries [45]. Apart from introducing the above electrochemistry inert carbon materials, some functional carbon bases showed superior. For example, graphene oxide (GO) with wealthy functional GO oxygen groups (–OH, –COOH) can also release free H+ in the aqueous electrolyte. Thus GO can effective protonation of PANI during the charging process, which resulting in more oxidized N (-N+=, -N+-) in PANI backbone. So the GO-doped PANI can transfer more charge and doping anions during discharging/charging processes. As illustrated in Fig. 3g, h, the GO composited PANI electrodes using proton from graphene oxide (GO) as effective doping species showed a significantly improved zinc-ion storage/rate performance (0.1 A g−1, 233 mA h g−1 and 5 A g−1, 100 mA h g−1) than non-functional carbon composited PANI/RGO and pure PANI cathodes (0.1 A g−1, 175 mA h g−1 and 5A g−1, 11 mA h g−1) [35]. To clearly illustrated the electrochemistry mechanism, Wan et al. prepared the PANI/carbon felts (CF) cathode and studied the dual-ion insertion/extraction mechanism by ex-situ spectra of the electrodes at discharge/charge states. As displayed in Fig. 4 a, in the initial discharge process, the doped Cl− removed from semi- oxidation state PANI cathode associated with the disappears of the Cl− peak, simultaneous Zn2+ interacts with reduced PANI (new peaks emerged at 90, 476/500, and 1022/1024 eV). At the following charge process, Zn2+ migrate out the electrode accompanied by the interaction of CF3SO3 − rather than Cl− for stronger H-bond interaction between oxidized PANI and CF3SO3 −. Because the S 2p (169 eV), S 2 s (232 eV), and F 1 s (688 eV) are detected in the XPS spectra of PANI/CFs at the first fully charged state (Fig. 4b). Moreover, the hybrid mechanism showed a supercapacitor-liked action, which was beneficial to the fast kinetics of charge carrier transfer and the morphology and structure stability. Thus it exhibited good rate capability (95 mAh g−1 at 5 A g−1 in Fig. 4c) and outstanding cycling performance with high capacity retention (92% after 3000 cycles at 5 A g−1) (Fig. 4d) [38]. Except for PANI as the host materials for storage ions, it also can act as the intercalator or surface coating for inorganic zinc ion cathodes, and relatively studies would discuss in the conductive polymer intercalator section. (3) PANI-based copolymers About the molecular modification, copolymers based on PANI main chain and tunable functional groups were widely investigated for their broader pH range in weak-acid/neutral electrolytes, and relative copolymers were list in Fig. 5 . Generally, there are several types of structure modification on based on PANI: One is introducing sulfo group, where sulfonic acid can reversible protonation and deprotonation combining with usually acid electrolyte. Thus, Shi et al. developed a sulfo-self-doped PANI (PANI-S), in which the -SO3 − group acts as the self-dopant and proton reservoir can maintain a high acidic local environment around the polymer skeleton and facilitate the redox process in the weak acid electrolyte (1 M ZnSO4). The detailed reaction mechanism of PANI-S was illustrated in Fig. 6 a. During the first reduction process (R1), the protonated –NH+= and –NH+- reduced to –NH- corresponding to the partial reduction of SO4 2− and the -SO3 − self-dopant interacts with the H+ and Zn2+ cations in the electrolyte. Therefore, the -SO3 −H+ part becomes an internal proton reservoir and maintains a low local pH value around the polymer backbone. Then the concentration of internally protonated –NH+- increase during the second reduction process (R2). While the reverse charge process involved the oxidation of –NH- (O) (Fig. 6b). Overall, the self-doping strategy stabilized the cathode reaction environment endowing PANI-S a high capacity of 184 mAh g−1 (0.2 A g−1) excellent rate capability (~130 mAh g−1 at 5 A g−1) and long cycle life with a capacity of 110 mAh g−1 (over 2000 cycles ~100% coulombic efficiency at 10A g−1) [45]. The second one is introducing phenolic hydroxyl group including aminophenol, aminosalicylic acid, which can realize the phenol-quinone transformation and change the environment around the polymers. For example, Mu et al. synthesized three kinds of copolymers: poly(aniline-co-o-aminophenol) [46], poly(aniline-co-m-aminophenol) [47] and poly(aniline-co-5-aminosalicylic acid) (poly(Ani-co-5-ASA)) [48] with different morphology based on PANI main chain via various methods. These synthesized polymers with meta- or ortho- position –COOH, –OH groups can realize reversible oxidation/reduction, which was accompanied by the deinsertion/insertion of zinc ions (Fig. 6c). Besides, these functional groups enhanced its weak acid tolerance (pH ≈ 4.8) resulting in 97.7% coulombic efficiency (after 200 cycles with retention 83.8% at the current of 5 mA) (Fig. 6d). Also, additional active monomers can adjust pH values around the copolymer electrode and enhance electrolyte tolerance (pH≈5). The third strategy is introducing anions doped redox-active center phenothiazine derivative into the PANI chain obtained the poly(aniline-co-N-methylthionine) (PANMTh) [49], poly(aniline-co-azure B) (PANAB) [50], and poly(aniline-co-azure C) (PANAC) [51]. Here, the phenothiazine active center in the copolymer chain can adjust pH around the copolymer electrode and contribute to the quantity of stored charge for the reversible doping/dedoping of Cl-, thus provided stable cyclability and high capacity. For example, PANAC was obtained by incorporating azure C (AC) units into the PANI chain via a facile copolymerization method. As demonstrated in Fig. 6e, the introduced AC units owned “proton-self-regulation” capability, namely, during discharge, owing to the proton release from the AC reduction process, the copolymer functions such as a smart “proton-self-supplier” to guarantee a high local proton concentration to facilitate the redox reaction and retain the electroactivity of copolymers. Hence, AC can boost the polymer electroactivity in near-neutral aqueous electrolytes (pH = 5) while enabling rapid electron/ion transport and deliver an impressive capacity of 306.3 mA h g−1 and a long lifespan (1000 cycle) than the primary PANI (Fig. 6f). To deeply investigated the mechanism of the heteroaromatic phenothiazine during the electrochemistry process, Wang’s group using methylene blue (MB), which constitutes heteroaromatic phenothiazine chloride salt with a cation N+ in the terminal dimethylamine group, as the active cathode. It revealed that MB molecules experience a two-electron transfer reaction process for charge storage via a radical pathway. And the CN+(CH3)2 group was the active site, co-insertion of CF3SO3 − and solvation Zn2+ bond with the N atom of the CN during the discharge process, while the discharge process was in reverse. Besides, a stable radical intermediate was generated and detected during the electrochemical process. These radical intermediates can lower the energy barrier and enhance the intrinsic electrochemical reaction kinetics, thus it showed excellent rate capability (capacity retention of 40.7% at 500 C), and long cycle life (20 000 at 100 C) [52]. Another method is the hybrid system, which merged the above manners. For example, a self-standing t-CNTs-PA-PE cathode was designed and fabricated by engineering a large π-electron conjugated system between PANI and PEDOT: polystyrene sulfonate (PSS) on CNTs homogeneously. PSS acts as an internal proton reservoir for the structural transformation of nonprotonated nitrogen in PANI chains, which ensured the composite's high redox reactivity (238 mAh g−1, at 0.2 A g−1) and good cycling stability during charge/discharge (1500 cycle, efficiency 100%) [53]. Polypyrrole (PPy), as a branch of conjugated amine, owning high conductivity and reversibility was investigated for zinc batteries. Moreover, it showed less sensitivity to electrolyte composition and pH that broaden its application prospect. And the electrochemistry mechanisms of the Zn-PPy system in chloride/citrate electrolyte are elucidated by the reactions in Fig. 7 [54]. Studies on electrolytes elucidated that the Zn-p-toluenesulfonic anions doped PPy battery had better biocompatibility in the simulated body fluid (SBF) and phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) electrolyte [55]. Whereafter, a polypyrrole fiber/graphene composite couple with phosphate-buffer saline electrolyte (SBF, PBS) was assembled. The two-dimensional (2D) graphene planes provided faster electron transfer channels and more electrochemistry reaction sites than the pure PPy fiber cathode. Thus the composites achieved high conductive (141 S cm−1) and surface area (561 m2 g−1) resulting in an impressive rate capability and capacity of 264 Wh kg−1 [56]. Besides, PPy can be coated on the surface of inorganic materials by in-situ self-polymerization. Usually, the existence of PPy can not only alleviate the decay caused by dissolution but also improve the conductivity of the electrode, such as the ZnO/Ag/polypyrrole (ZAP) composite [57] and MnO2@PPy core-shell nanorods [58]. Recently, electrodeposited Zn and PPy onto polyethylene terephthalate (PET) films electrode would increase the flexibility and exhibit the unique function of a short circuit chromatic warning: turning yellow at 0 V, which provide the Zn-PPy batteries show great potential in biocompatibility and smart electronics for energy storage [59]. Polyindole (PIn) contains pyrrole and benzene ring (Fig. 5), usually with stability and good electrical conductivity in the doped state. Most researches about its properties, synthesis, and application in lithium batteries [60-62]. The studies on zinc batteries were rarely. Early, Pandey et al. constructed a Zn/1 M ZnSO4/polyindole battery with high open-circuit potential (1.45 V), good reversibility and efficiency at a capacity of 90 Ah kg−1 [63]. Cai et al. proposed the zinc/polyindole battery has good cycle stability at pH 6.0 in the ZnCl2 electrolyte [64]. Whereafter, they constructed an aqueous zinc/electrospun poly(5-cyanoindole) (PCIn) fibers secondary battery system. After optimization of the electrospinning parameters, the fibers with an average diameter of 115 nm with larger specific surface areas showed a high voltage 2.0 V and high capacity (107 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C) and long cycle life (retention 75% after 800 cycles) [65]. 2.2.2 Conjugated hydrocarbons Polyparaphenylene (PPP) is the bipolar conducting polymer, and it can use as both cathode and anode for its large voltage gap between the p-type and n-type reactions (Fig. 5, Table 1). While there are rare reports for its irreversible overoxidation reaction at high voltage. Besides, the low coulombic efficiency and self-discharge phenomenon exist. To solve these issues, Liu et al. developed an ionic liquid-surface functionalized polystyrene (PS) spheres hybrid electrolyte for rechargeable Zn/PPP batteries. The interaction between the components of the ionic liquid and the oxygen-plasma treated PS spheres facilitates the fast movement of the Zn2+ upon polarization and the voltage profiles are largely enhanced. Moreover, the confinement of the IL electrolyte in the PS spheres framework allows the formation of porous and dendrite-free zinc deposits upon cycling. Thus, the Zn/PPP rechargeable battery exhibits long-term cycling stability over at least 300 cycles with a coulombic efficiency of more than 96% [66]. 2.2.3 Conjugated thioether Polythiophene (PTh) is a general organosulfide polymer with sulfur heterocycle, and its electrochemical properties have been studied also in lithium batteries. However, the low capacity hindered their studies in secondary batteries for its doping limitation [67]. Studies about PTh-based derivates were listed in Fig. 8 , and the earliest reported PTh for zinc battery is the Zn//propylene carbonate, Zn(ClO4)2, LiClO4 electrolyte//PTh system. However, the insufficient rate performance and poor cycling life hindered its further application [68]. In light of this issue, grafting the conjugated thioether on the conductive chain was adopt. For instance, the poly(vinylexTTF) merged the conductive poly(acrtylene) line with conjugated thioether active monomer exTTF can enhance the electronic conductivity. The tetrathiafulvalene center with π-extended system exhibited a suitable redox potential for the two-electron oxidation, thus the battery featured high performance, charge/discharge rates 120 C (30 s) and an ultra-long lifetime of over 10,000 cycles (retention 86%) [69]. The other common conjugated thioether compound is poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT), which is the most successful conducting polymer in commercial applications for its high conductivity stability and high transparency. Some researches based on the PEDOT cathode were assembled with ionic liquid [70] or ionic liquid additive all-solid electrolyte [71]. For example, Gonzalo’s group constructed the first Zn-PEDOT battery based on imidazolium-based IL electrolyte ([C2mim][dca]), which was beneficial to the deposition and dissolution of zinc anode, thus the battery showed excellent cyclability, performing over 320 cycles with no indication of short circuit [70]. The insufficient capacity is the fatal flaw of PEDOT for energy storage, while it as the conductive intercalator in inorganic materials were widely investigated, and relative studies will discuss in the following section. 2.2.4 Conductive polymer intercalator In the above sections, we have listed and analyzed studies about conductive polymers as the host materials for zinc ion battery cathodes. Simultaneously, part of conductive polymers can act as intercalators for inorganics, typical including PANI and PEDOT. As intercalator, their function is mainly to strengthen interlayer stability and provide extra electrochemistry activity. Therefore, we will discuss the application of conductive polymer intercalator-based inorganic for zinc batteries in this section. For the PANI-based inorganic hybridized cathode materials, Here, PANI as an intercalator was implanted in the interlayer of vanadium or manganese-based materials, which can enhance the interlamination stability and enlarge interlamellar spacing. For example, Wang’s group prepared the polyaniline (PANI)-intercalated MnO2 nanolayers through an interface reaction. The nanoscale size of the layered MnO2 and the guest polymer in the interlayer can efficiently strengthen the extended layered structure and eliminate the hydrated H+/Zn2+ -insertion-induced phase transformation or structure collapse. Thus, the efficiently facilitates the charge storage with unprecedented stability of 200 cycles at a high capacity of 280 mA h g−1 (90% utilization of MnO2), as well as achieving long-term stability of 5000 cycles at the utilization of 40% [71]. The PANI, except as an intercalator for MnO2, was also been inserted into the V2O5 layers [72]. For example, the graphene-like PANI-VOH nanosheets were prepared by in-situ polymerization after a pre-intercalation of aniline (AN) into the interlayers of exfoliated vanadium oxygen hydrate (VOH, V2O5.·n H2O) (Fig. 9 a). The PANI-VOH cathode coupled with a zinc electrode exhibited a larger specific capacity of 323 mAh g−1 (current 1 A g−1). Here, PANI can enlarge the lamellar spacing (from 13.1 Å to 14.2 Å) and suppress the phase transformation and relieve the intercalation stress. Also, PANI participated in the electrochemistry and showed an extra redox peak at 0.76/ 0.78 V (Fig. 9c) indicating the protonation/deprotonation reaction in PANI along with the intercalation/deintercalation of Zn2+, both being contributors to the reversible capacity (Fig. 9b). Thus, the PANI-VOH showed superior capacity than the pure VOH no matter long cycle-life (retention 80% and 66% for the PANI-VOH and VOH at 1A g−1 after 800 cycles, respectively) or rate performance (186 mAh g−1 for PANI-VOH and 116 mAh g−1 for VOH at 5 A g−1, respectively) (Fig. 9d, e) [73]. Another report figured out the π-conjugated structure of PANI can also block the electrostatic interactions between the Zn2+ and the host O2−, which facilitates the Zn2+ diffusion kinetics [74]. Except for the in-situ polymerization after a pre-intercalation method, a molecule-exchange reaction was adopted to prepared the PANI-inorganic hybridized composites [75]. The above studies indicated the PANI-intercalated inorganic hybridization provided a promising applicable approach for improving the performance in a range of oxide-based energy storage materials. Analogous to PANI, PEDOT also as the intercalator or coating layer for zinc inorganic batteries materials can stabilize the interlayer structure and suppress structural collapse. PEDOT as the coating layer in the surface of MnO2 [76], V2O5 [77] and VO2 [78], which can suppress the structural pulverization and dissolution of MnO2, restrain structural collapse of V2O5, simultaneously increases zinc ion/electron transport kinetics and provide extra capacity for the VO2 system, respectively. On the other hand, PEDOT as the intercalator were inserted into the interlamination of NH4V3O8 (NVO) and V2O5, in which PEDOT-NVO was obtained by oxidatively polymerized EDOT monomers to PEDOT while the insertion of just-synthesized PEDOT into the NVO-layered structure occurred simultaneously. As illustrated in Fig. 10 a, PEDOT as the intercalator effectively enlarged the interlayer spacing of 10.8 Å (against 7.8 Å for the single NVO), this change not only huge boosted the capacity (345.5 mAh g−1 for PEDOT-NVO vs. 261.5 mAh g−1 for NVO at 0.05 A g−1) and rate performance (Fig. 10b, c), but induced the mixed-valence to alleviate the stress and strain that accompany zinc-ion (de)intercalation, thus enhancing the capacity and cycling stability (ultra-long lifetime 5000 cycles with a capacity retention of 94.1%) (Fig. 10d) [79]. Recently, an oxygen vacancy (Vö)-V2O5-PEDOT (VöVP) with tunable Vö concentration was achieved via a spontaneous polymerization strategy. Here, the PEDOT provided Vö and large interlayer spacing resulting high capacity of 449 mAh·g−1 at a current density of 0.2 A·g−1 and excellent cyclic performance of 94.3% after 6000 cycles [80]. In brief, the above sections were the summarization and optimization strategies of conductive polymers for zinc batteries, in which conjugated conductive amine, thioether, hydrocarbons polymers were earliest studied for their easy synthesis, high conductivity and high voltage at doped state. Nevertheless, their capacity and stability were insufficient for the existence of charge repulsion interaction between structural units at the full doping (oxidation) state [27]. Thus their polymer including PPy, PPP, PIn, PTh and PEDOT usually delivered stable capacity lower than 200 mAh g−1. In especial, PANI practically achieved a relatively higher capacity of ~170 mAh g−1 (the full-doping state with a theoretical capacity of 295 mA h g−1) was widely studied. Aiming at enhancing weak-acid and netural electrolyte tolerance, copolymerization not only modified the surroundings of electrolytes but introduced extra active centers that offered capacity was a decent method. These effects make it possible for the practical application of conductive polymers. 2.3 Nitroxide radical polymers Nitroxyl radical polymers were synthesised mainly based on the active monomer 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl or 2,2,5,5-tetramethylpyrrolidine-1-oxyl-3-yl,. typical polymers, including poly(2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl-4-yl methacrylate) (PTMA), poly(2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine-1-oxyl-4-yl vinyl ether) (PTVE), poly-(TEMPO-substituted norbornene) (PTN) and Poly(2,2,5,5-tetramethylpyrrolidine-1-oxyl-3-yl ethylene oxide) (PTEO) [27]. Nitroxyl radical polymers for energy storage with high discharge voltage and stable cycling performance were early applied in lithium batteries system, and with relatively few were studied on nitroxyl radical polymers zinc batteries. Typically, PTVE with hydrophilic was coated on a glassy carbon substrate and applied as the cathode for zinc battery. Combining the high ionic conductivity of the aqueous electrolyte, PTVE showed a high rate performance (131 mA h g−1 at 60C) high output voltage platform of 1.7 V and long cycle life (>500 cycles) [81]. Whereafter, Luo et al. tuned the operating voltage triggered by selecting anions for stronger electrostatic interaction of the anion with the organic radical resulting in a higher operating voltage of the zinc organic batteries. They pointed that the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the oxidation state of the PTVE unit (denoted as P+) is mainly located at the -N+=O group. Nevertheless, there are few electrons of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) of P+ at the -N+=O group (Fig. 11 a). These confirmed that the -N-Ȯ groups in PTVE are active sites for redox reactions. During the charging process, the nitroxyl radicals (-N-O.) turn into oxoammonium cations (-N+=O) and the insertion anion (Cl−, SO4 2− or CF3SO3 −) will balance the charge insertion into Zn2+ ions Then, DFT in Fig. 11b explained this characteristic and explicitly pointed out that the higher binding energy between anion and PTVE, the larger ΔG for the battery reaction leading to a higher operating voltage of the batteries. In Fig. 11c-e displayed the anion effect on the electrochemical performance of Zn//PTVE batteries using three types of anion SO4 2−, CF3SO3 −, and ClO4 −. Here, the batteries in these electrolytes displayed discharge voltage platform at 1.77, 1.58, and 1.53 V, respectively. Further, reaction kinetics in Fig. 11f indicates that the charge/discharge process shows a diffusion-controlled behavior. In particular, the well-delocalized electronic structure of CF3SO3 − facilitates its dissociation from the PTVE host, leading to good reversibility and excellent cycling stability (1000 cycles, retention 77.0%) [82]. Winsberg et al. reported the first flow zinc organic battery with a wide voltage window, shown in Fig. 11g. This system contained three types of nitroxide radical copolymers cathode: poly(TEMPO) (PTMA), P(TEMPO-co-PEGMA) and P(TEMPO-co-METAC) (Fig. 8), organic carbonate-based or water based electrolyte and zinc anode. Both of the carbonate and water systems showed ultra-stable cycle performance. The nitroxide radical enabled a stable potential window up to 2 V in aqueous media, without the utilization of toxic and expensive heavy metals. Furthermore, this work enabled the stable flow-zinc battery as an energy storage system on large scales with consecutive 500–1000 cycles (Fig. 11h) [83]. Further, an investigation of ice-templated porous electrodes used PTMA cathode, Zn(ClO4)2·6 H2O EC/DMC (3:7) electrolyte and zinc counter electrode was performed. This ice-templating allows for a great variety of opportunities in manipulating the properties of organic battery electrodes and, hence, in optimizing their performance [84]. A novel type of TEMPO-containing catholyte was utilized successfully in a semi-organic polymer/zinc hybrid-flow battery (pHFB), combining the well-defined block copolymer PTMA63-b-PS35 as redox-active cathode and Zn2+ (aq)/Zn0 (s) as the anode active material as well as EC/DMC/DEC (v:v:v=1:1:1) with 0.5 M Zn(ClO4)2·6 H2O as the solvent and supporting electrolyte, respectively. The semi-organic pHFBs delivered a flat charge /discharge plateaus and superior coulombic efficiency of 99.8% after 1000 consecutive cycling. Besides, this reversible pHBF system could operate in the presence of oxygen and water, which further improved its universality. [85]. In summary, despite the nitroxide radical with the one-electron reaction delivered high reversibility and smooth voltage, the insufficient capacity and difficult synthesis were unavoidable. Moreover, the scarcity of monomers is deadly for further design and synthesis. Thus fewer studies were conducted on them in the past decade. 2.4 Conjugated carbonyl Conjugated carbonyl compounds owned high theoretical capacity, fast reaction kinetics, reversibility and structural diversity. Therefore, carbonyl materials offer a wide range of possibilities to meet the demands of next-generation energy storage materials [86]. The general electrochemistry mechanism was based on the reversible evolution of CO and CO-. B+ (B+ represents H+, Zn2+ or hydratization Zn2+), while the anode is the reversible plating/stripping of zinc. Vast studies were conducted on for their wide distribution in the organism and chemical raw materials. However, carbonyl compounds were generally soluble in organic aprotic electrolytes leading to a rapid capacity decline [21], while this phenomenon was partially suppressed in the aqueous electrolyte system. Thus, conjugated carbonyl compounds for zinc batteries have opened up new possibilities for the application of carbonyl organics, and their diversified structures have triggered another tide of the studies on zinc organic batteries after conducting polymers. And corresponding studies mainly focus on settling the issues including relatively lower discharge plateau (at the range of 1.0-0.6 V), dissolution in electrolytes (part of simple carbonyl compounds), insufficient electrical conductivity. Here, we listed the studies about carbonyl compounds for zinc-organic batteries in Fig. 12 and summarized the corresponding methods to address these issues in the following section. Briefly, three aspects are divided: hybridization confinement (inorganics/carbon or membrane modification); structure design (rigid conjugated structure design, polymerization, heteroatom (N, S) or electro-drawing groups introduce); electrolyte modification (quasi/all-solid-state or low-temperature electrolyte system). (1) Inorganic/carbon materials and membrane confinement These two methods were the early reported path to prolong the cycling life of zinc-carbonyl compounds batteries. Utilizing the porosity of carbon or inorganic materials to suppress the dissolution of active materials was feasible [25]. Confining p-chloranil into the porosity zeolite matrix made the zeolite-modified deliver a long life than the pure one [87]. Further, Kundu et al. deeply investigated the insertion action of p-chloranil and figured out a unique water-assisted phase transition between the electrolyte and interface that do harm to the reversible structural evolution of p -chloranil. Confining p-chloranil inside the nanochannels of mesoporous carbon CMK-3, which can tame the phase transition and ensure a long cycle life [88]. Besides, to minimize the dissolution of naphthoquinone (NQ)-based organics (NQ, dichlone, APh-NQ), Fu’s group trapped them into the nanoporous structure of the CNT framework. Owing to the high electrical conductivity and confinement of the CNT network, the composite cathodes showed stable and high rate cyclability [89]. Using the permselectivity of the membrane to suppress the shuttle effect of the materials or discharge products does favor to the improvement of the cycling ability. Here, Chen’s group reported the Nafion membrane to obstruct the discharge products and explored a series of quinone compounds including, 1,4-naphthoquinone (1,4-NQ), 9,10-phenanthrenequinone (9,10-PQ), 1,2-naphthoquinone (1,2-NQ), 9,10-anthraquinone (9,10-AQ), calix[4]quinone (C4Q) for zinc batteries (Fig. 13 a), and lucubrated the coordination insertion process of C4Q that described in Fig. 13b. Further, the FT-IR spectrum confirmed the -CO groups were the active sites (Fig. 13c). They figured out that the dissolution of discharge products was the ringleader for capacity decay. In-situ UV-vis spectra confirmed the Nafion membrane can effectively hinder the diffusion of discharge products and prolong the cycling life of the batteries (Fig. 13d). Thus, calix [4] quinone (C4Q) coupled with a Nafion membrane exhibited a high capacity of 335 mA h g−1 and a long life of 1000 cycles with a capacity retention of 87% at 500 mA g−1 in rechargeable metal zinc battery (Fig. 13e) [90]. However, the membrane confinement strategy is palliative because the intrinsic solution peculiarity of the materials remains unchanged. Also, the cost and durability of the membrane need to take into consideration. (2) Optimization electrolytes systems Recently, low or ultra-low temperature electrolytes with specific application prospects were investigated and some attempts to restrain the dissolution of cathode were reported [39]. For example, Sun et al. developed an ultra-temperature battery system based on the p-chloranil cathode, a 4 M Zn(BF4)2 electrolyte with a low freezing point (−122 °C) and high ion conductivity (1.47 mS cm−1 at −70 °C) and zinc anode. The battery achieved a high discharge specific capacity of 101.4 mA h g−1 and an average voltage of 1.2 V (vs. Zn2+/Zn) at −30 °C. It also exhibited an excellent rate capacity and long cycling stability with 94% capacity retention over 1000 cycles [91]. This research knocked the novel door for the application of carbonyl compounds in the low-temperature energy storage field. Moreover, Yang et. al. studied the organic electrolyte system based on the three kinds of quinones (DMBQ, PAQS, 14PAQ.) and proposed that the intercalation of Zn2+ into organic materials was relatively easy with fast intrinsic kinetics in nonaqueous electrolytes compared to that of transition metal oxides’ strong electrostatic interaction between the crystal lattice of the inorganic host and the divalent Zn2+ cation. The Zn(TFSI)2/acetonitrile system exhibited the best performance due to its excellent transport and electrochemical properties [92]. (3) Conjugated molecular structure design Except for the materials confinement or low-temperature electrolyte strategy mentioned above, exploring and designing rigidly conjugated or innate insoluble organics was an effective strategy to improve the cycle and rate performance of zinc-organic batteries. Moreover, the electrolyte would affect the insertion action of materials. For example, Nam et al. developed a battery with rigid geometry and layered superstructure composed of a redox-active triangular phenanthrenequinone-based macrocycle (PQ-Δ) cathode, 3 M Zn(CF3SO3)2/H2O electrolyte and zinc anode. Here, the rigid structure of the PQ-Δ realized the insertion of hydrated Zn2+, which was proved by the ex-situ FT-IR spectrum (Fig. 14 a and b). Moreover, as illustrated in Fig. 14c, the relative coordination energy of H2O molecules was calculated, and the results figured out that Zn2+ coordinating two H2O molecules at each carbonyl group was the most thermodynamically stable state. Meanwhile, the insertion mechanism contributed to the charge-screening effect and low desolvation energy dications, which made the interfacial resistance between the cathode and electrolytes decrease effectively. Thus PQ-Δ achieved a high capacity (203 mAh g−1) and extremely stable cycle-life (99.9% retention after 500 cycles at 150 mA g−1) [93]. PQ-MCT with the same structure as PQ-Δ, while delivered different insertion behavior in the different electrolyte systems. The developed zinc organic battery with a phenanthrenequinone macrocyclic trimer (PQ-MCT) cathode, ZnTFMS/DMF non-aqueous electrolyte and zinc anode could operate at all-weather environment (−70–150 °C). The operation mechanism depends on the reversible coordination reaction (CO/CO-0.5 Zn conversion) with PQ-MCT (Fig. 14d). Notably, the non-aqueous nature of the system and the formation of a Zn2+-DMF complex can efficiently eliminate undesired hydrogen evolution and dendrite growth on the Zn anode. Thus the battery exhibited a super-long life (20000 cycles) and a wide temperature range (Fig. 14e and f) [94]. Besides, Wang’s group proposed others organics (PTO, DTT) with conjugated or rigid structure and insoluble property in commonly electrolyte solvents. PTO with an inherent low solution in the aqueous electrolyte was applied in a mild aqueous electrolyte, and the coordination insert reaction during the reversible electrochemical process was uncovered. The PTO cathode delivered a high specific capacity of 336 mAh g−1 at a current density of 0.04 Ag−1, and excellent cycling capability (retention 70% over 1000 cycles) [95]. They also proposed a high mass loading aqueous zinc battery using sulfur heterocyclic quinone DTT as the cathode. The inherent low solubility and adjacent carboxyl groups can store both protons (H+) and Zn2+, which delivered a high capacity (210.9 mAh g−1) and ultra-stable cycling life (retention of 83.8% after 23,000 cycles) [96]. Besides, atom substitution sometimes played an important part in the rate and cycle performance. Wang et al. investigated the structure–function relationship of O and N atom for the NTCDA and NTCDI for the performance of zinc battery, respectively. The results indicated that the nitrogen from ammonia substituted the oxygen in the COC bond can homogenize the electrochemistry plateau and suppress the dissolution of materials [97]. (4) Carbon hybridization To solve the sluggish electronic conductivity of materials, carbon hybridization including in-situ synthesis or loading active materials on carbon-based (graphene, graphene aerogel, CNT) was a cost-effective strategy to enhance their surface area and conductivity, which ensure the high active sites utilization ratio and rate capability. For example, Cao’s group prepared the PPTCDA/graphene aerogel (GA) (PPTCDA/GA). The composites with large open pores promoted the transfer speed of electrons and increased the contact area and storage of electrolytes, thus the composites showed a high specific capacity of 281 mAh g−1 (100 mA g−1, efficiency 100%) [98]. Many hydroxy groups can be converted into redox-active carbonyl groups for zinc batteries at the initial discharge-charge process. For instance, a composite cathode with cross-conjugated polycatechol (PC) and graphene was prepared, wherein the PC with hydroxy groups can be converted into redox-active carbonyl groups at the initial discharge/charge. Graphene can accelerate electron transfer and ortho carbonyl can facilitate coordination effects that stabilize the electrode structure endowing the composites a high specific capacity of 355 mAh g−1 and long cycle life (retention 74.4% after 3000 cycles) [99]. Inspiring by nature, dopamine with two redox-active quinone groups was available for zinc ion storage via the reversible catechol/ortho-quinone reaction. Thus, Yue et al. prepared a flexible, free-standing, binder-free polydopamine (PDA) coated carbon nanotube (CNT) composite as the cathode material for aqueous zinc ion batteries [100]. Here, CNT with a nanoporous structure framework can trap quinone monomers and enhance electrical conductivity and cyclability. These works provided the possibility of applying biomedical materials in zinc batteries. (5) Introduction of heteroatom The introduction of heteroatom can enhance the intrinsic conductivity accompany the elevation of polymer, such as grafting active groups on the conductive polymer line and artificially designing or synthesizing compounds with S atom were widely studied. Recently, Patil et. al constructed an ultra-robust aqueous zinc-metal battery using poly(catechol) redox copolymer (P(4VC86-stat-SS14)) as the cathode and concentrated Zn(TFSI)2 aqueous solution as a stable electrolyte. The conductive polymer line and catechols units created a conducive environment for strong, yet reversible, coordination complex formation with Zn2+, which resulted in high active utilization (94%, 324 mAh g−1, 1C), superior rate performance (324 mAh g−1, 20% capacity retention at 1350C) and ultralong cycling stability (48 000 cycles at 30C) [101]. Chen’s group constructed a battery with poly(benzoquinonyl sulfide) (PBQS) cathode, 3 M Zn(CF3SO3)2 aqueous electrolyte and zinc anode, and confirmed the bonding of Zn2+ ions with carbonyl oxygen atoms in PBQS by ex-situ spectrum analysis. The existence of S atom endowed PBQS higher plateau than a quinone monomer, also improved the rate performance [102]. Further, Zhang’s group systematically studied a series of sulfide quinones, in which sulfur showed some synergies reaction during the electrochemistry process. Whereafter, they proposed a ladder-like polymer PDB with bipolar redox-active, which went through an irreversible p-type electrolyte anion-doping on PDB upon the first oxidation process, followed by an in-situ formation intermolecular S-S interaction on the conjugated thioether (C-S-C) group that further stabilize PDB molecules (Fig. 15 a and b). And the subsequent electrochemistry process was the reversible bond/break out of the O-Zn bonds. Further DFT calculations in Fig. 15c indicated that the neutral state shows a small energy bandgap (ΔE) of 1.91 eV, suggesting a good electronic conductivity of such a kind of conjugated structure. Upon oxidation the LUMO was no change and still located on benzoquinone, suggesting the oxidized state was stable enough. Thus the battery delivered a fast electrochemistry ability (Fig. 15d) and an ultra-stable cycle-life with retention of 75.2% after 10,000 cycles at 20 A g−1 (Fig. 15e) [103]. Then, poly(2,5-dihydroxy-1,4-benzoquinonyl sulfide) (PDBS) with thioether bonds was synthesized, in which the sulfur side effectively coordinated with divalent Zn2+ leading to the reorientation of chain configuration. This unique mechanism implying that the valence electrons in the S atom displayed a binding effect between S site and Zn center. Hence, it is inferred that sulfur atoms have some contribution to zinc storage [104]. 2.5 Imine compounds Imine and tertiary amine-based materials with CN/CN groups were studied in recent years. They can combine with monovalent or divalent cations and exhibit high redox activity and reversibility. For tertiary amine compounds, a novel organic cathode, namely, 1,4 bis(diphenylamino)benzene (BDB) can realize a 2-electron redox in two steps corresponding to the two distinct phase transitions process involving BDB/BDB+·A− and BDB+·A−/BDB2+·2A− (A− represent the SO4 2−, CF3SO3 −) that showed in Fig. 16 a, and the anode is the reversible plating/stripping of zinc. Moreover, the evolution process has also been confirmed by in-operando XRD and solid-state UV-vis studies. The BDB cathode delivered a high average voltage of 1.25 V and achieved a capacity of 130 mA g−1 with 75% capacity retention after 1000 cycles using a highly concentrated aqueous electrolyte and cellulose nanocrystal (CNC) membrane [105]. Except for external electrolyte and membrane modification, the functional groups at the edge also affect the physical chemistry peculiarities of materials. The introduction of electron-donating groups can also affect the voltage and physical properties (conductivity, solubility). For example, Wang et al. first compared the electrochemical behaviors of phenazine(PNZ) and its analog DAP [106]. The existence of hydrophilic groups (–NH2) on the peripheral positions of the PNZ molecular structure would raise the probability of hydration through hydrogen bond formation and promote the dissolution of DAP in aqueous electrolytes. Thus, less hydrophilic groups on PNZ peripheral positions endowed it a capacity of 204 mAh g−1 and cycle stability (100 cycles with retention 89% at 0.1 A g−1) (Fig. 16b). Further mechanism studies indicate that the reversible redox CN (CN) bonds can bond (break) with Zn2+, while the anode is the evolution between Zn2+ and Zn. Whereafter, a series of PNZ-based polymers poly(o-phenylenediamine) (PoPD) with sufficient CN active group were prepared in different conditions. The PoPDH exhibited a specific capacity of 318 mAh g−1 at 0.05 A g−1 and a high-rate capacity of 95 mAh g−1 at 5 A g−1 as well as excellent cyclic stability (retention 66.2% after 3000 cycles) [107]. Analogously, the introduced electron-withdrawing also made an elevation of the voltage, such as diquinoxalino [2,3-a:2′,3′-c] phenazine (HATN) and its derivant HATN-3CN. Fig. 16c showed the proton insertion process of HATN in a mild electrolyte. And the unique π-conjugated aromatic structure of HATN strengthened π-π intermolecular interactions and suppressed the dissolution of HATN in aqueous electrolyte. Thus HATN achieved a highly reversible structural evolution during the electrochemistry process (retention of 93.3% after 5000 cycles at 5 Ag−1) and superior electrochemistry capacity (405 mAh g−1 at 100 mAg−1). A recent report also pointed out that the extended π-conjugated systems of HATN can enhance electrochemical stability, conductivity, and reversible capacity [108,109]. Analogously, the introduced electron-withdrawing (–CN) on the HATN edge can lower the HOMO/ LUMO energy gap on the aromatic of HATN. Therefore, electron-withdrawing –CN not only improved the voltage but further promoted the dispersion of the negative charge on N atoms, which can stabilize the reactive intermediate during the discharge/charge process for the accelerated kinetics [110]. Besides, some bio-inspired materials also owned electrochemistry activity. For instance, riboflavin (RF) （Fig. 17 ) utilizing an isoalloxazine ring as the redox center can reversibly take up and release zinc ions through a two-electron transfer process and showed high cyclic stability (145 mAh g−1 after 3000 cycles with a capacity retention of 92.7%) [111]. Recently, Song’s group reported a novel quinone/pyrazine hybrid structure cathode − 5,7,12,14-tetraaza-6, 13-pentacenequinone (TAPQ). The specific multiple electroactive CO and CN bonds made the TAPQ set a new record for organic cathodes in zinc ion batteries upon capacity (443 mAh g−1 within 0.1–1.6 V). Further mechanism characterizations and DFT calculations revealed that the TAPQ presented H+ dominated H+/Zn2+ co-insertion action. This study leaded a novel way to design materials with the combination of CO and CN active groups [112]. In summary, imine compounds owning high capacity, superior redox reversibility and wide-range structural tunability were widely investigated. The multiple cations (H+, Zn2+, hydration ions) insertion mechanism endow them with fast kinetics and high capacity. However, the inferior voltage, eutectic property and low electronic conductivity were the main hinders to their application in zinc batteries, which need further to optimize to realize their practical application. 2.6 Conjugated nitrile compounds Nitriles with electron-poor molecules for energy storage presented highly reversible redox chemistry. Tetracyanoquinodimethane (TCNQ) is a typical nitrile material with an excellent electron acceptor extensively used as an electron acceptor for organic semiconductors. Its strong electron-withdrawing groups (–CN) , inherent ability to accept electrons and consequent higher redox potential (2.8–3.2 V vs Li+/Li) formation of the stable aromatic ring account for the high reversibility. TCNQ-based derivates as energy storage materials for lithium, sodium batteries were reported [27]. Chola et al. confined TCNQ molecules inside the nanostructures of the newly prepared covalent organic framework-CCP. Cyanogroup makes TCNQ an electron-deficient molecule by negative inductive effect endowing the electron affinity of the molecule very high consequently make π-π stacking interaction with the covalent organic frameworks (COF) plane. Thus COF can accelerate the shuttle of zinc ions and suppress the effusion of TCNQ resulting in the enhanced performance as well as electrode stability [113]. Whereafter, tetracyanoanthraquinodimethane (TCNAQ) as a modified derivative of TCNQ, was used as the cathode of zinc battery. As illustrated in Fig. 16d the cyano group is the reversible active center. During the discharge process, the process -CN change to – CN− and bond with 0.5 Zn2+ was accompanied by the conversion of CC and CC at the quinone analogue conjugated center. DFT calculation illustrated that TCNAQ owned higher LUMO energy than the anthraquinone (AQ) leading to an elevated working potential and attractive energy density compared with that of AQ (Fig. 16d). The battery demonstrated an attractive energy density of 151.9 Wh kg−1 and a capacity of 95 mAh g−1 (retention of 81% after 1000 cycles at 500 mA g−1). This research provided an insight into the nitriles organic cathode material for aqueous zinc batteries [114]. In summary, TCNQ and its derivates as cathode materials for zinc batteries possess high voltage and superior reversibility. Nevertheless, the soluble, less available structure monomers and weak designability impede their further investigation. Hence, seeking and exploring modifiable monomers is of great concern for their development. 2.7 COF/MOF materials Metal-organic frameworks (MOF) and covalent organic frameworks (COF) possessing the feature of pre-designable and highly ordered structures, inherent porosity, and rich physicochemical. Thus those materials exhibit broad potential applications in gas separation or storage, sensors, catalysis, membrane, remembrance magnets, etc. [115,116]. Through elaborately designed organic functional linkers and metallic nodes endow two-dimensional materials not only diverse structures, special physicochemical properties but also tunable electrical conductivity. MOF and COF materials as energy storage materials are being studied a lot for their in-plane covalent bonds providing electron conduction peculiarity [117-119]. Also, large size and nanoscale thickness make two-dimensional materials with high surface area and abundant active reaction centers. The above excellent merits draw researchers' attention to applying MOF and COF materials in zinc-ion batteries. Thus, the design and synthesis of MOF and COF materials for zinc batteries will be a hotspot. 2D conductivity MOF generally been constructed via the planar coordination between metal nodes (Fe, Cu, Ni, Co, etc.) and conjugate planes organic ligands owning multitropic (–OH, –NH2, -SH, etc). For example, Nam et al. prepared a 2D conductive MOF using the multitropic ortho-substituted hydroxy monomer-2,3,6,7,10,11-hexahydroxytriphenylene (HHTP) and Cu2+-- Cu3(HHTP)2 [120]. The unique 2D framework and one-dimensional channel structure provide a host room for the high diffusion rate and low interfacial resistance for the insertion of hydrated Zn2+ (Fig. 18 a). Interestingly, the ex-situ XPS at different states of the material shown in Fig. 18b illustrated that both the quinoid component and the copper in Cu3(HHTP)2 participated as redox-active centers during the discharge–charge process. Thus the redox of Cu2+ provided extra capacity and high voltage (0.8 V on average). Furthermore, the Cu3(HHTP)2 cathode follows the intercalation pseudocapacitance mechanism, namely the kinetics are not limited by the diffusion of the cations. Therefore, Cu3(HHTP)2 exhibits a superior rate performance and a high reversible capacity of 228 mAh g−1 at 50 mA g−1. At a high current density of 4000 mA g−1 (~18C), 75.0% of the initial capacity is maintained after 500 cycles (Fig. 18c, d). Liu’s group proposed a zinc battery with a porous metal–organic coordination polymers (MOCP) nanosheets cathode, ZnSO4/MnSO4 solution electrolyte and zinc anode. The addition of MnSO4 triggered the synergy effects between MOCP and MnO2, which can enhance the electrochemical performance due to MnO2 can provide extra capacity and stability [121]. Two-dimensional (2D) porous crystalline covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are integrated from pre-designed symmetric organic building units and self-assembled by π-π stacking. Their inherent robust networks and open pores could facilitate the infiltration of electrolyte ions provide electrochemical storage through faradaic and non-faradaic processes. Khayum et al. utilized hydroquinone-linked β-ketoenamine COF-HqTp acting as a Zn2+ anchor in an aqueous rechargeable zinc ion battery (Fig. 19 a). As illustrated in Fig. 19b, the CO and N–H from the adjacent layers of the COF as the insertion sites for interlayer coordination interaction of Zn2+ ions. Moreover, due to the well-defined nanopores and structural organization, the large electron-rich backbone endowed HqTp high capacity (276 mA h g−1 at 125 mA g−1) and rate capability (126 mA h g−1 at 1250 mA g−1) as well as high capacity retention (94% after 1000 cycles) [122]. Besides, a novel phenanthroline-based covalent organic framework (PA-COF) was applied as cathode for zinc-ion battery (Fig. 19c) [123]. Experimental analysis and theoretical simulations demonstrated the phenanthroline unit was the active ion-binding site. Moreover, a proton peak can be detected after the first discharge (Fig. 19d). Through inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy and deuterium solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance, the co-insertion quantitatively rate of Zn2+ (60%) and H+ (40%) were confirmed (Fig. 19e). The PA-COF presented a high capacity of 247 mAh g−1 (current 0.1 A g−1) and with only 0.38% capacity decay per cycle during 10,000 cycles at a current density of 1.0 A g−1 (Fig. 19f). Recently, ’s group developed a series of polypyrene cathodes (LPy-1, LPy-2, CLPy, CL16Py, CL12Py) with different linking patterns and electronic structures as Cl− hosting organic cathodes for aqueous Zn dual-ion batteries (Fig. 19g, h) [124]. Altering the linking patterns on the pyrene monomers realized the tunable of the redox activity of the polypyrenes. The investigation demonstrated the porous polypyrene CLPy with 1,3,6,8-linking pattern delivered a high specific capacity of 180 mA h g−1 at 50 mA g−1 and 38,000 cycles at 3 A g−1 (Fig. 19i). In summary, MOF/COF as organic cathodes for zinc organics batteries is still in the embryonic stage and of great potential to be a comprehensive scheme to resolve most problems in the future. 2.8 Comparision of different materials The previous presentations and figures have given a rough impression of various types of materials. Moreover, an understanding of the strategies toward better electrochemistry performance has formed. Through the rough and comprehensive comparison about the performance of the five kinds of materials were presented in Fig. 2, we know that the conjugated nitrile with relatively high voltage, while the capacity and modifiability were circumscribed. Similarly, part of amine compounds owning high capacity (exceed 400 mAh g−1), however, such a low voltage was the deadly flaw that binder their application in zinc organic batteries. Radical nitroxide polymers with the superior of the highest voltage and rate performance among the organic cathodes, regrettably, the low capacity and cycle instability made them impracticable. Carbonyls and conductive polymers were puzzled by the low electronic conductivity and low capacity contribution, respectively. Therefore,all the materials have advantages and disadvantages, so what kinds of materials were suitable for zinc organic batteries? To answer this question, an intuitionistic comparision about electrochemical properties of various zinc organic batteries cathodes upon their voltage, capacity, energy density and power density were presented in Fig. 20 and Table 2 . The gravimetric energy densities of conjugated carbonyl compounds with a wide distribution (form 10 to 350 Wh kg−1) and the performance of conjugated nitrile and radical nitroxide radical polymers were in the average (Fig. 20a). Though conjugated part of amines (PNZ, HATN and PA-COF) delivered a superior capacity, the lower output voltage restricted their further development. It is encouraging that the gravimetric energy densities of some carbonyls (C4Q, PTO, HqTp-COF and TAPQ, etc.) and conductive polymers (PANI-GO, PC/G and P(4VC86-star-SS16)) achieved superior capacity and energy density. Besides, the Ragone plot in Fig. 20 b indicated that the conjugated carbonyl and conductive polymers still presented higher energy and power density than others. Thus we deemed that the materials based on the carbonyls or conductive polymers, which including PANI-based carbon/inorganic hybridization materials and their copolymers, have the potential value to realize practical application, and worth further study. 3 Summary and outlook Zinc-ion batteries are receiving increased attention due to their low cost, high safety and high eco-efficiency. However, it is still a big challenge to develop because of the limitations of suitable cathode materials. Organic materials, with sustainable production, ubiquitous in nature and high reversible electrochemistry are attractive alternative cathode materials for zinc-ion batteries. From the above section, we have a clear understanding of the classification, electrochemistry mechanism, development status and electrochemical performance of major types of organic cathode materials. Through analyzing their relationship between voltage, capacity, rate, cycle life and active groups of organic electrode materials, we summarized strategies to solve these issues, and proposed our opinions in the following sections. 3.1 Design and modification strategies The problems of each material were general existence, and strategies around improve their performance were diverse, also some methods affect more than one part. However, the four core factors (voltage, capacity, rate performance, cycle life) were fixed. Therefore in this section, we would fully discuss and analyze related strategies at the level of molecular design, morphology or structure optimization and electrolyte environment, also propose perspectives around the four factors. 3.1.1 Voltage of zinc organic battery Voltage was determined by the electroactive group or moiety even electrolyte. The active monomer with different structures displayed a biggish difference in the plateau voltage or polarization voltage. (1) For the molecular design, p-type moieties owned higher voltage and conductivity than n-type ones. Therefore, introducing high energy density p-type moieties as the polymers’ main chain or main active groups can improve the voltage of the materials. (2) DFT including Molecular-level orbital (LUMO, HOMO), the energy gap between HOMO and LUMO, Molecular electrostatic potential (MESP), etc. provide ideas for the molecular structure design. Introducing electron-withdrawing groups (e.g., -Cl, -F, -Br, -S and –CN) lowers the LUMO energy of aromatic compounds, which facilitates the reduction and improves the reduction voltage. (3) The optimization electrolyte solvent affects the voltage, also the solute will. Usually, the stronger interaction between the electrode and solute solution would improve the operating voltage. Low viscosity solvent does favor to lower the ohmic polarization resulting in a high discharge plateau. 3.1.2 Capacity of zinc organic battery Capacity includes theoretical capacity and practical capacity. Theoretical capacity obeys the equation: C theo = n F/M w, while the practical capacity is associated with many factors including morphology, electronic and ionic conductivity. (1) At the level of molecular design, increasing transferred electrons value n and simplifying molecular structure (M w) can improve the capacity in theory. (2) Architecting morphology or structure with high surface area or intrinsic nanostructure by controllable synthesis. Generally, in-situ polymerizing the active materials on high surface area 1D, 2D or 3D carbon base (CNT, GO, RGO, SWCNT, etc.) or elaborate molecular structure design to construct intrinsic nanochannel structure such as 2D MOF or COF are feasible methods. These strategies can increase the penetration of the electrolyte resulting in the more exposed reaction sites and shorten the diffusion pathway, which does a favor to the capacity. Besides, some hybrid materials also can provide extra capacity such as the GO, PEDOT and PSS, because of their internal proton reservoir and provides enough H+. However, these strategies were palliatives for the introduction of carbon materials will dilute the mass/volume energy density of the cathodes. Thus upon materials morphology control, this method should be adopted as appropriate. (3) Electrolyte components will affect the electrochemistry behavior. Aqueous electrolytes are usually accompanied by H+ or hydration Zn2+ insertion, which can boost the utilization of active sites and enhance the capacity. 3.1.3 Rate of zinc organic battery Rate capacity is associated with electronic/ionic conductivity. (1) For the improvement of intrinsic electronic conductivity, the introduction of conductive polymer skeleton, heteroatom (N, S) or metal conductive primaries into the carbon skeleton or extension π-conjugated structure were effective approaches to increase their intrinsic electronic conductivity. Line or ladder polymers with thioether bonds can induce π-electron delocalization between benzene rings and provide an alternative charge transfer pathway. Besides, the π-conjugated system and CN bonds can enhance π-electron delocalization and facilitate electron migration resulting in the promotion of the conductivity. Metal-ligand coordinate covalent bonds with metal coordination center and conjugated structure usually show superior conductivity. (2) At the level of macroscopic feature, increasing the surface area or hybridizing with carbon materials mentioned in the capacity section also can improve the rate performance. (3) The third is the optimization of ionic conductivity, which is determined by the electrolyte salts and solvent. Usually, anions with smaller ionic radius do a favor to the p-type cathode, and aqueous electrolyte owned high ionic conductivity than an organic system. Besides, the coordination action (H+, Zn2+ or hydrated zinc ion) also does avail to the electrochemistry rate. 3.1.4 Cycle for zinc organic battery Cycle life is of great importance for the application of zinc batteries. Generally, the dissolution of active materials in the electrolyte is a major problem for organic electrode materials over a long period. (1) For the molecular design concept, polymers including crosslinking, linear polymer, coordination polymers were the most efficient strategies to solve this problem fundamentally. Rigid structure, edge hydrophobic groups or extend π-conjugated structure can also suppress the dissolution issue. Besides, burgeoning 2D or 3D topological polymer structure – MOF/COFs owning a conjugated plane and orderly porous structure makes up for conductivity flaw and capacity decay perfectly. (2) Nanocarbon confinement strategy by using carbon materials including CNT, GO, CMK-3 as well as novel COF with orderly nanopore structure, was general adopted to enhance the conductivity and suppress the dissolution issue. (3) Optimization of electrolytes divides into the dissolution and anode dendritic growth. Electrolyte additive, ionic liquids, organic solvents, membranes and quasi/all-solid electrolytes were mainly methods. Besides, with the development of cathode, the anode seemed the key hinder for the application of zinc-organic, thus still vast efforts should be done in this field. 3.2 Perspectives for zinc organic battery From the above summary and discussion, we know that based on the diverse flexible and abundant active structures, great room for the development of organic materials for zinc batteries has been presented. Various strategies have been adopted for the improvement of the performance including hybridization, morphological control and electrolyte modification, however, the bottom-up principle that the materials design and inherent molecule structure should be put first. About materials design and preparation. According to the development history of the organics for energy storage, the exploration of novel active monomers with different charge storage mechanisms is challenging and urgent. Moreover, the present materials system has not reached the limit. For instance, the front section mentioned carbonyls and conductive polymers with complementary peculiarity among capacity, voltage and conductivity. Thus design materials with p-type moieties as the conductive polymers’ main chain (PANI, PTh, PPP, etc.) and n-type grafting units (quinone, TCNQ or imine parts) as dominating capacity contributors or their copolymers were available. And some studies have released this sign, such as the merging catechol active monomer with PPP conductive main chain based – PC/G cathode and the polyacetylene (PAc) based – P(4VC86-star-SS16)) cathode. As illustrated in Fig. 20, both of them show superior performance on the voltage, capacity and energy power density. Another orientation is elaborately designed 2D conductive COF or MOF polymers. Because their innate 2D conjugated plane structure and space channel structure endowed them with good electronic conductivity and ions migration/storage capability. Also, some conduction electron nodes such as the N, S and metal center (Cu, Ni) further make an elevation on the conductivity. Although their present electrochemistry performance is of varying quality [120,122-124]. Because the relative studies in this field still in their initial stage, while some achievements were prominent in other energy storage systems [118,125]. About the novel application of zinc organic materials. Uniquely, organics based on the doping or conversion process showed superior to inorganic lattice evolution on fast intrinsic kinetics for its lower energy barrier during the electrochemistry process, thus organics owned inherent superior on special circumstances. For example, with the exploration of the low-temperature batteries and electrolytes [39,91,120,126,127], organics have the incomparable potential for all weather (−95 °C − 150 °C) batteries. This specific field may be new for the application of organics for zinc batteries. In summary, we provide an overview of organic electrode materials for zinc organic batteries, including their functional groups, fundamental knowledge, progress and modified strategies upon the three levels: materials design concepts, morphology structure optimization and electrolyte environment. Then made a comprehensive comparison of the voltage, capacity, rate and cycle life of these materials, also a detailed summary, discuss and viewpoint have been proposed on these four core factors. Ultimately, made a bold forecast about the materials for zinc organic batteries, we believed the materials merged carbonyls, conductive polymers based linear, 2D conductive COF and MOF are the most promising compounds worth further study. Of course, they still have a broad space for the new active materials with different charge storage mechanism need to explore. Simultaneously, we have faith in overcoming these issues through molecular design and structural optimization to make zinc-organic an efficient, clean, and safe new energy storage system. Mater. 31 (2021) 2010127. Shibing Zheng received his M.S. (2018) degree from Yanshan University. Currently, he is a Ph.D. candidate in Prof. Zhangliang Tao’s group. His research focuses on the design and synthesis of organic materials for rechargeable lithium, sodium, zinc-ion batteries. Qiaoran Wang received her undergraduate degree from the Dalian University of Technology in 2019. She is currently a master student at Nankai University. Her research focuses on exploring advanced materials for aqueous zinc ion battery Yunpeng Hou received his B.S. degree from Northeastern University in 2017, and then joined the Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry in College of Chemistry, Nankai University. His research focuses on the design and development of electrolytes for high-performance rechargeable batteries. Lin Li received his B.S. degree from Nanchang University (2016). He then joined the Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry under the supervision of Prof. Shu-Lei Chou. His research focuses on advanced materials for energy storage and conversion devices Zhanliang Tao received his Ph. D. degree of inorganic chemistry at Nankai University in 2005 and now is a professor in the College of Chemistry, Nankai University. His research interest focuses on electrochemical energy storage and conversion.

coredata.dc:description: Energy sustainable development has stimulated the pursuit of an eco-friendly energy storage system. Carbon peak and neutrality targets oriented energy storage development will guide the way of further studies on batteries system. However, conventional batteries system (lead-acid batteries, lithium-ion batteries) based on ungreen transition metal oxide, flammable electrolytes or hazardous metals cannot keep pace with the development of society sooner or later. Thus, vast explorations on the advanced rechargeable battery systems were conducted. Compared with other battery systems, zinc ion battery systems with inherent safety, low cost were widely investigated. Especially, the zinc organic batteries based on the eco-efficiency organic cathodes were promising alternative advanced batteries for future energy storage systems. Therefore, various organics and different electrochemistry mechanisms were explored in the zinc batteries system. Herein, a timely review on elaborate analysis about functional groups, fundamentals, progress accompanied by the discussion on the four core issues: voltage, capacity, rate performance, cycle life was presented. Specifically, aiming at these issues, three levels of solution strategies: materials design concepts, morphology structure optimization and electrolyte environment were summarized and proposed for the development and innovation of zinc organic batteries.
